dt: {bc}to engage the attention or energies of
{bc}to take up (a place or extent in space)

dt.t: the fireplace will {wi}occupy{/wi} this corner of the room

dt: {bc}to take or fill (an extent in time)

dt.t: the hobby {it}occupies{/it} all of my free time

dt: {bc}to take or hold possession or control of
{bc}to fill or perform the functions of (an office or position)

dt.t: will {wi}occupy{/wi} the newly created office of chancellor

dt: {bc}to reside in as an owner or tenant

dt.t: {it}occupies{/it} an apartment on a two-year lease

et: Middle English {it}occupien{/it} "to take possession of, hold, inhabit, take up space in, fill, keep (oneself) busy," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}occuper, occupier,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}occupāre{/it} "to grasp, appropriate to oneself, take possession of, fill up (space, a position), forestall," from {it}oc-,{/it} assimilated variant of {it}ob-{/it} {et_link|ob-|ob-} + {it}-cupāre,{/it} intensive derivative of {it}capere{/it} "to take, seize, catch" {ma}{mat|heave:1|}{/ma}

The source of the {it}-i-{/it} in Anglo-French {it}occupier{/it} and Middle English {it}occupien,{/it} retained in Modern English, is unclear, as continental French has only {it}occuper.{/it} The verb {it}occupy,{/it} common in later Middle and early Modern English, was very infrequently used in the 17th and first two thirds of the 18th century; it has been suggested that this was due to the sense "to have sexual intercourse with (a woman)," which impinged by connotation on the less charged meanings and led to a taboo on any use of the word. When the socially unacceptable sense fell out of circulation {it}occupy{/it} once more became a generally used word.
shortdef: to engage the attention or energies of
to take up (a place or extent in space)
to take or fill (an extent in time)
